Mathematical Background¶

This section describes the mathematical background to the WDM wavelet transform.

  • Introduction

  • Regularised Incomplete Beta Function

  • Meyer Window

  • WDM Wavelets

  • The Discrete WDM Wavelet Transform

  • Glossary

  • References

Introduction¶

The Wilson-Daubechies-Meyer (WDM) wavelet basis is widely used for gravitational wave (GW) data analysis. While far from being the only available choice, the WDM basis wavelets have some properties that make them particularly suitable for this purpose: they are well separated in frequency (in fact, the wavelets have compact support in the frequency domain) which helps to make connections with other GW data analysis which is almost exclusively done in the frequency domain, and they provide uniform tiling in both time and frequency. The WDM wavelets were first introduced to GW data analysis in Ref. [1] (see also Ref. [2]) and are used in coherent WaveBurst (CWB; Refs. [3] and [4]).

Regularised Incomplete Beta Function¶

The WDM wavelets use the regularised (normalised) incomplete beta function, \(\nu_d(x)\),

(1)¶\[\nu_d(x) = \frac{ \int_0^x \mathrm{d}t \, t^{d-1} (1 - t)^{d-1} } { \int_0^1 \mathrm{d}t \, t^{d-1} (1 - t)^{d-1} } .\]

This is defined for \(x \in [0, 1]\) and acts as a smooth transition function (or compact sigmoid-like function) from 0 to 1. The parameter \(d\) controls the steepness of the transition; see Figure 1.

The function \(\nu_d(x)\) is implemented in WDM.code.utils.Meyer.nu_d().

Meyer Window¶

The WDM wavelet transform is based on the Meyer window function, which is defined in the frequency domain as

(2)¶\[\begin{split} \tilde{\Phi}(\omega) = \begin{cases} \frac{1}{\sqrt{\Delta\Omega}} & \text{if } |\omega| < A, \\ \frac{1}{\sqrt{\Delta\Omega}} \cos\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\nu_d\left(\frac{|\omega| - A}{B}\right)\right) & \text{if } A \leq |\omega| \leq A + B \\ 0 & \text{if } |\omega| > A + B \end{cases} ,\end{split}\]

where \(\omega=2\pi f\) is the angular frequency, \(A\) and \(B\) are two positive angular frequency parameters satisfying \(2A + B = \Delta\Omega\), and \(\Delta\Omega\) is the wavelet bandwidth. The parameter \(A\) is the half-width of the flat-top response region while \(B\) is the width of the transition region; see Figure 2.

The function \(\tilde{\Phi}(\omega)\) is implemented in WDM.code.utils.Meyer.Meyer().

WDM Wavelets¶

Henceforth, we will work with time \(t\) (e.g. in seconds) and frequency \(f\) (Hertz) rather than angular frequency \(\omega=2\pi f\). This is inline with the rest of the GW data analysis community which tends to work with frequency.

Consider a time series with cadence \(\delta t\) and duration \(T=N \delta t\). In order to define the WDM wavelet transform it ie necessary to choose a number of frequency bands \(N_f\). We will assume that \(N_f\) divides \(N\) exactly (if not, then the time series can be padded as necessary), and \(N_t = N/N_f\) is the number of time bands. Other derived quantities that follow from this are \(\Delta \Omega = 2\pi \Delta F\) where \(\Delta F = \frac{1}{2 \delta t N_f }\) and \(\Delta T \Delta F = \frac{1}{2}\).

The WDM wavelets are constructed from the Meyer window function. In the frequency-domain they are defined as

(3)¶\[\begin{split} \tilde{G}_{nm}(f) = \begin{cases} \exp(-4\pi i n f \Delta T) \tilde{\Phi}(2\pi f) & m=0 \\ \exp(-2\pi i n f \Delta T) \left( C_{nm}\tilde{\Phi}(2\pi [f-m\Delta F]) +C^*_{nm}\tilde{\Phi}(2\pi [f+m\Delta F]) \right) & 0<m<N_f \\ \exp(-2\pi i Q f \Delta T) \left( \tilde{\Phi}(2\pi [f+N_f\Delta F]) + \tilde{\Phi}(2\pi [f-N_f\Delta F]) \right) & m=N_f \\ \end{cases} ,\end{split}\]

where \(Q=2n+(N_f\,\mathrm{mod}\,2)\) and the coefficients \(C_{nm}\) are defined to be 1 is if \(n+m\) is even, and \(i\) if \(n+m\) is odd and are implemented in WDM.code.utils.utils.C_nm().

The WDM wavelets \(\tilde{G}_{nm}(\omega)\) are implemented in WDM.code.discrete_wavelet_transform.WDM.WDM_transform.Gnm().

To understand the wavelet definitions it is best to focus first on the middle case, \(0<m<N_f\). The index \(n\) describes a time shift by an amount \(\Delta T\). The index \(m\) describes a frequency shift of the wavelet by an amount \(m\Delta\Omega\). Unfortunatelt, this doesn’t quite holde for the cases \(m=0\) and \(m=N_f\) which are handled separately.

The WDM wavelets are plotted in the frequency domain in Figure 3.

The wavelets in the time-domain, $g_{nm}(t)$, are constructed by taking an inverse Fourier transform. The wavelets \(g_{nm}(t)\) are implemented in WDM.code.discrete_wavelet_transform.WDM.WDM_transform.gnm().

Uisng \(N=512\), \(\delta t=1\), and \(N_f=16\), several examples of the time-domain WDM wavelets are plotted in Figure 4, Figure 5 and Figure 6.

The WDM wavelet basis has the following orthonomality property,

(4)¶\[\delta t \sum_{i=0}^{N} g_{nm}(t_i) g_{n'm'}(t_i) = \delta_{nn'} \delta_{mm'} .\]

The Discrete WDM Wavelet Transform¶

Hello.

Glossary¶

  • \(t\): Time (e.g. seconds).

  • \(f\): Frequency (e.g. Hertz).

  • \(\omega\): Angular frequency (e.g. radians/second). Defined as \(\omega=2\pi f\).

  • \(\delta t\): Time series cadence (seconds). Named dt in WDM_transform.

  • \(f_{\rm Ny}\): Nyquist frequency, or the maximum frequency (seconds). Defined as \(f_{\rm Ny}=\frac{1}{2 \delta t}\). Named f_Ny in WDM_transform.

  • \(A\): With of flat-top response in the Meyer window (radians/second). Named A in WDM_transform.

  • \(B\): With of transition region in the Meyer window (radians/second). Named B in WDM_transform.

  • \(\Delta \Omega\): Angular frequency resolution of the wavelets (radians/second). Satisfies \(\Delta \Omega = 2A + B\). Named dOmega in WDM_transform.

  • \(\Delta F\): Frequency resolution of the wavelets (Hertz). Satisfies \(\Delta F = \frac{\Delta \Omega}{2\pi}\). Named dF in WDM_transform.

  • \(\Delta T\): Time resolution of the wavelets (seconds). Satisfies \(\Delta T \Delta F= \frac{1}{2}\). Named dT in WDM_transform.

  • \(d\): Steepness parameter for the Meyer window. Named d in WDM_transform.

  • \(q\): Truncation parameter for the Meyer window. Named q in WDM_transform.

  • \(N_f\): Number of frequency bands for the wavelets. Named N_f in WDM_transform.

  • \(N_t\): Number of time bands for the wavelets. Named N_t in WDM_transform.

  • \(N\): Number of points in the time series. Satisfies \(N = N_t N_f\). Named N in WDM_transform.

  • \(T\): Duration of the time series (seconds). Satisfies \(T = N \delta t\). Named T in WDM_transform.

  • \(n\): Time index for the wavelets. In the range \(n\in\{0,1,\ldots, N_t-1\}\).

  • \(m\): Frequency index for the wavelets. In the range \(m\in\{0,1,\ldots, N_f\}\).

References¶

[1] (1,2)

V. Necula, S. Klimenko and G. Mitselmakher, Transient analysis with fast Wilson-Daubechies time-frequency transform, Journal of Physics: Conference Series 363 012032, 2012. DOI 10.1088/1742-6596/363/1/012032

[2] (1,2)

N. J. Cornish, Time-Frequency Analysis of Gravitational Wave Data, Physical Review D 102 124038, 2020. arXiv:2009.00043

[3]

S. Klimenko, S. Mohanty, M. Rakhmanov & G. Mitselmakher, Constraint likelihood analysis for a network of gravitational wave detectors, Physical Review D 72, 122002, 2005. arXiv:gr-qc/0508068

[4]

S. Klimenko et al., Method for detection and reconstruction of gravitational wave transients with networks of advanced detectors, Physical Review D 93, 042004, 2016. arXiv:1511.05999

[5]
